title: 유사
subtitle: Similarity & virtuality
exampleEn: That's no different from lying.
description: Means 'no different from' / 'practically the same as.'
tip: Often used to criticize or emphasize equivalence to an undesirable act.

title: 추가·포함
subtitle: Addition & inclusion
exampleEn: Not only is it expensive, it also tastes bad.
description: Formal ‘not only…but also,’ frequently adding negative info.
tip: Sounds bookish/formal; great for essays, reviews, or newsy tones.

resources.title: 거니와 "Not only" | Live Class Abridged
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

title: 추가·포함
subtitle: Addition & inclusion
example: 한국어는 물론이고 중국어도 할 수 있어요.
exampleEn: Not only Korean, I can also speak Chinese.
description: ‘Not to mention…’ / ‘in addition to…’ to stack a stronger item after a given item.
tip: Common in spoken and written Korean; pairs naturally with 도 to add the extra item.

resources.title: GU5.6 ~은/는 물론이고 (not to mention, to say nothing of)

title: 추가·포함
subtitle: Addition & inclusion
exampleEn: This food is worse than just having ramen.
description: ‘Not as good as doing A’ (doing B would be worse than A).
tip: Sounds a bit evaluative/critical; often contrasts a fancy option with a simpler one.

title: 습관 & 태도
subtitle: Habits & tendencies
example: 어릴 때 자주 놀러 가곤 했어요.
exampleEn: When I was young, I used to go out and play often.
description: Marks a past habit or repeated action (similar to ‘used to’).
tip: You’ll see it with time phrases (옛날에, 예전에) or frequency adverbs (자주).

resources.title: TOPIK II 문법 수업 (6): [ 곤하다, 기 일쑤이다, -아/어 대다 ]

title: 정도·강조
subtitle: Degree & emphasis
exampleEn: It’s quite (really) difficult.
description: A litotes (double-negative) meaning ‘very/quite’ with emphasis.
tip: Translate to a natural intensifier in English (‘pretty’, ‘quite’, ‘really’) not literally ‘not easy’.

title: 정도·강조
subtitle: Degree & emphasis
exampleEn: I’m simply grateful.
description: Formal ‘only/merely’ showing limitation or humility.
tip: Frequent in speeches or formal writing; set phrase: 감사할 따름입니다.

resources.title: Learn Korean Ep. 127: 뿐이다 & 따름이다 “Only”
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

title: 정도·강조
subtitle: Degree & emphasis
exampleEn: I’m extremely happy (couldn’t be happier).
description: ‘To the utmost degree’ for strong praise/complaint about a state.
tip: Common with adjectives like 기쁘다/만족스럽다/불편하다 + 기가 이를 데 없다.

title: 의도
subtitle: Intentions & plans
exampleEn: They keep trying to interfere.
description: ‘Be about to try to / attempt to’ (often negative nuance or pushy intent).
tip: Use when the subject’s ‘trying to’ itself is the point (annoying, intrusive, etc.).

title: 의도
subtitle: Intentions & plans
exampleEn: This time, I’m determined to succeed.
description: Firm intention/resolve (stronger than 단순 계획).
tip: Close to ‘I fully intend to…’—use for decisive plans or resolutions.

title: 추측·가능성
subtitle: Guess & probability
exampleEn: There’s no choice but to do it this way.
description: Indicates inevitability / lack of alternatives.
tip: Often paired with 그래서/결국 to explain why something was inevitable.

title: 추측·가능성
subtitle: Guess & probability
exampleEn: I can’t believe it.
description: Emphatic inability/impossibility (with the focus on circumstances).
tip: Contrast with 지 못하다 (skill/ability) vs (으)ㄹ 수 없다 (circumstance/possibility).

title: 제외
subtitle: Exclusion
exampleEn: Without your help, it’s impossible.
description: ‘Without X’ with emphasis on necessity of X.
tip: Often pairs with 불가능하다/어렵다/안 된다 to stress indispensability.

resources.title: Lesson 74: (topic on ‘regardless of’ / contrastive forms; use as a fallback reading)

title: 제외
subtitle: Exclusion
exampleEn: No one but you knows.
description: ‘Except for / other than’—excludes all but the specified noun.
tip: Often used with negative predicates (모르다/없다/못하다).

resources.title: HOW TO USE 말고 IN KOREAN SENTENCE

title: 제외
subtitle: Exclusion
exampleEn: Other than this, there’s no other way.
description: Formal ‘other than/except for’.
tip: Slightly more formal than 말고는; reads more written/polite.

title: 비교
subtitle: Comparison
exampleEn: This movie isn’t as good as the previous one.
description: ‘Not as good as N’ (N만 못하다).
tip: Politer/softer than saying something is ‘bad’ outright.

title: 비교
subtitle: Comparison
exampleEn: This job is doable / worth doing.
description: Assesses adequacy or worth doing of an action/state.
tip: 시험 볼 만하다 / 가 볼 만하다 are common ‘recommendation’ patterns.

resources.title: Learn Korean Ep. 78: "Worth Doing" | 만하다
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

title: 비교
subtitle: Comparison
exampleEn: Compared to last year, it has improved a lot.
description: ‘Compared to…’—sets a standard for comparison.
tip: You can flip to 에 비해(서) in casual writing; both are fine.

title: 시간 표현
subtitle: Time expressions
exampleEn: I fell asleep while studying.
description: Shows interruption/change while doing an action.
tip: Follow it with a 2nd action that cuts in (잠들다/넘어지다/떨어뜨리다).

resources.title: Live Korean Class | While (면서, 동안, 다가)
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

title: 시간 표현
subtitle: Time expressions
exampleEn: If you keep doing it like this, you’ll fail.
description: Warns that continuing the current action will lead to a bad result.
tip: Common in advice/warnings: 그렇게 먹다가는~, 그렇게 늦잠 자다가는~.

resources.title: 다가는 Continuing Actions | Live Class Abridged
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

title: 시간 표현
subtitle: Time expressions
exampleEn: As I kept studying, my skills improved.
description: After doing something for a while, you realize/arrive at a result.
tip: Narrative/explanatory; great in personal stories and reflections.

resources.title: Live Korean Class | [Advanced] ~다 보니까 “Realizing”
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

title: 시간 표현
subtitle: Time expressions
exampleEn: He was sick, and in the end he went to the hospital.
description: Speaker’s observation of A followed by a related outcome B.
tip: Usually the subject is 3rd-person or someone other than the speaker for A.

resources.title: Learn Korean Ep. 72: 더니
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

title: 시간 표현
subtitle: Time expressions
exampleEn: Contact me as soon as you arrive.
description: ‘As soon as / just as’—immediate sequence or ‘the way (someone does)’.
tip: Two core senses: immediacy (오자마자) and ‘the way’ (말하는 대로).

resources.title: Live Korean Class | [Intermediate] "As soon as" 대로
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

title: 시간 표현
subtitle: Time expressions
exampleEn: You’ll get results in proportion to how much you work.
description: ‘As much as / to the extent that’—proportional relationship.
tip: Pairs naturally with 만큼…-다 structure for comparisons.

resources.title: Live Korean Class [Intermediate] ~만큼 “As Much As” & “Because”
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

title: 원인 표현
subtitle: Cause expressions
exampleEn: Because it rained, the picnic was canceled.
description: Uncontrollable external cause leading to a negative result.
tip: Natural with weather/accidents/outside conditions; tone is a bit apologetic/explanatory.

resources.title: Live Korean Class | [Intermediate] ~는 바람에 “Because of”
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

title: 원인 표현
subtitle: Cause expressions
exampleEn: I was late because of the traffic jam.
description: Cause with a subtle sense of blame/responsibility (more formal than 바람에).
tip: Use carefully in sensitive contexts—sounds like you’re attributing fault.

resources.title: Live Korean Class | “Because of” 탓에
resources.channel: Learn Korean with GO! Billy Korean

title: 인용을 나타낼 때
subtitle: Reporting / quoting
exampleEn: I'm telling you it's not true!
description: Cites reported information as the reason or basis for a suggestion, action, or insistence (short for -(느)ㄴ다고 하니까).
tip: Use when the justification comes from an external source (news, teacher, friend).

title: 인용을 나타낼 때
subtitle: Reporting / quoting
exampleEn: I heard it will rain tomorrow, is that right?
description: Confirms information the speaker previously heard from someone else.
tip: Polite confirmation; without -요, it is casual.

title: 인용을 나타낼 때
subtitle: Reporting / quoting
example: 기상청에 의하면 내일 눈이 올 거래요.
exampleEn: According to the weather agency, it will snow tomorrow.
description: Formal source attribution: ‘according to N’. Distinct from N에 의해(서) which marks cause/agent.
tip: Use in reports/presentations to give authority to a claim.

title: 명사화
subtitle: Nominalisation & fact statements
exampleEn: It is certain that it is his fault.
description: Formal nominalizer used in written language to state facts or completed actions; more abstract than -기.
tip: Common in notices, reports, and concise memos (…함/…임).

title: 대조
subtitle: Contrast
exampleEn: Even though I did my best, I failed the exam.
description: Literary concessive connector conveying frustrated expectation or regret; stronger than -지만.
tip: Suited to literary/formal tones; rare in casual conversation.

title: 대조
subtitle: Contrast
exampleEn: Rather than feeling good, I feel at ease.
description: Refines or corrects a label: ‘not so much A as B’; polite way to offer a more accurate characterization.
tip: Avoid direct antonyms (e.g., 어렵다기보다는 쉽다). Offer a more precise alternative instead.

exampleEn: Whether it's hot or cold, you have to exercise.
I tried it because (they said) it was delicious.
Minsu says he's coming tomorrow.
Learning Korean is difficult.
Learning Korean is interesting.
As far as I know...
While you're going to the mart, buy some milk too.
Only after finishing homework can you play.
I came to Korea in order to learn Korean.
The result depends on your effort.
I'm busy cleaning and cooking (and everything else).
Take everything - books, pens, and all.
While the older brother is tall, the younger one is short.
I'll pay by card instead of cash.
It's as good as finished already.
There's no point in saying it, so it's the same whether you say it or not.
For that reason, I changed my decision.
I was so sick I thought I would die.
I was moved to the point of tears.
It's so cold that I can't go out.
I gave a speech while many people were watching.
A phone call came during the meeting.
I went traveling during vacation.
I'm studying right now.
I played after doing my homework.
I stopped by the mart on my way home.
While I was cleaning, I also organized things.
